text:
1. Write a function `F` that returns the tuple `(x, y, k)` where: `x` is the first positional argument and is mandatory, `y` is the second positional argument and is optional, `k` is an optional keyword argument. The optional arguments should have the following defaults: `y` defaults to `2x` , `k` defaults to `2y` . I wrote this as: 
```F(x, y = 2x; k = 2y) = x, y, k```
2. Write a function `G` just like `F` but with different defaults: `k` defaults to `2x`, `y` defaults to `2k`
```G(x, y = 2k; k = 2x) = x, y, k
> G (generic function with 2 methods)

G(1)
> MethodError: no method matching *(::Int64, ::typeof(k))
Closest candidates are:
  *(::Any, ::Any, !Matched::Any, !Matched::Any...) at operators.jl:538
  *(::T, !Matched::T) where T<:Union{Int128, Int16, Int32, Int64, Int8, UInt128, UInt16, UInt32, UInt64, UInt8} at int.jl:87
  *(::Union{Int16, Int32, Int64, Int8}, !Matched::BigInt) at gmp.jl:538
  ...

Stacktrace:
 [1] G(::Int64) at ./In[96]:1
 [2] top-level scope at In[97]:1```
How do I solve this?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

This is not possible with the current lowering of optional args and kwargs unfortunately, you would need to write this out manually. The confusing error message is probably because you defined a function named `k` before, otherwise it would just be an `UndefVarError`.

text: I would suggest just setting the default for your keywords to `nothing` , and then checking that case inside the function and doing the dependent assignment there.

elements.text: I would suggest just setting the default for your keywords to
, and then checking that case inside the function and doing the dependent assignment there.

text:
Ex.
```function G(x, y=nothing; k=nothing)
  if (isnothing(y) && isnothing(k))
    y = 2 * x
    k = 2 * x
  end
  ...
end```

elements.text:
function G(x, y=nothing; k=nothing)
  if (isnothing(y) && isnothing(k))
    y = 2 * x
    k = 2 * x
  end
  ...
end

text: Any singleton type will do if you need finer-grained control over dispatch.

elements.text: Any singleton type will do if you need finer-grained control over dispatch.

text: That doesn't catch the case where only `x` and `k` are defined. Unless you are on the latest nightly build, you should also prefer `y === nothing` over the `isnothing` here, as that would otherwise introduce type instabilities.
